title: Shadows
summary: Shadows help define hierarchy, depth, and interaction. In Green, they work together with other primitives to support clarity and visual balance.

sections.title: Designing with shadows
sections.section-content:
Shadows are used sparingly in Green to create depth and hierarchy when needed.

Our overall design language follows a flat approach, where surfaces are defined primarily by color and spacing. However, shadows can help emphasize components that appear above others â€” for example floating action buttons, popover menus, or modals.

sections.title: Shadow variants
sections.section-content:
We use six elevation levels from XS to 2XL. XS, S, and M are subtle shadows used to accentuate components or provide slight separation from the background when needed. L, XL, and 2XL are reserved for overlays, popovers, modals, and full takeovers - elements that require clear focus above other content.

Shadows should be applied consistently and with care. They are not decorative, but a way to communicate depth and interaction.
